Bom = good

DO NOT CLOSE LIPS ON THE FINAL “M”

Final “m” nasalizes preceding vowel

dia=day

final, unstressed "de" and "te"

Initial "ti" as in tia sounds like chee

popups.popupText:
ao = to the

ao = a + o

The “s” in Brasil has a “z” sound because it is between two vowels

The “l” in Brasil is pronounced has the sound of “u”

amanhã = tomorrow

~ = tilde (causes primary stress)

subPopups.popupText:
ao - a contraction of a and o

ao = to the
The definite article “the” is used with most countries in Portuguese.
Brasil - the final "l" is pronounced as if it were a “u”
amanhã - primary stress is on the final syllable

popups.popupText:
fazer = to do

você vai fazer = you are going to do

subPopups.popupText: você vai fazer = You are going to do.

popups.popupText:
ser = to be

Eu vou ser = I am going to be

Double “s” in missionário has the “s” sound.
The ´ (acute accent) causes primary stress

subPopups.popupText: Eu vou ser = I am going to be.

popups.popupText:
quanto = how much
Keep mouth closed for a nasal sound

tempo = time

Put the tip of the tongue against the teeth to avoid the exhalation of breath as happens with the “t” in time.

ficar = to stay

subPopups.popupText: quanto - pronounced with a closed mouth to preserve the nasal sound of “an”

dois anos = two years

The “s” becomes a z sound because it is between two vowels
